parameters.source_text:
Case 13-4
Reporting the Motorist with Epilepsy
A young man was brought into a private hospital seizure clinic, where the
following record was kept on him over the next four days:
3/22 9:47 a.m. Admitted to seizure clinic from Emergency Department (ED).
Reported seizure while walking to work. ... Patient reports one previous sei-
zure “just like this one” approximately four years ago... Rx diphenylhydan-
toin O.1Gm. No.2] sig: i tid.
3/24 EEG (electroencephalogram) confirms suspicion of grand mal. Pa-
tient pleads not to report case to Motor Vehicle Department. Says he only
drives 2 times a month—to care for mother who lives alone on the family farm.
Says distance is “about 10 miles.” Will consult hospital attorney, but consider
primary responsibility is to patient and patient's mother.
3/25 Attorney says law in California requires report of all seizure diagno-
ses. But does this conflict with medical ethics?

data.vignette: A 24-year-old man is seen in a hospital seizure clinic after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure on his way to work. He reports a similar event four years ago and admits he has continued to drive occasionally since then. EEG and exam support a diagnosis of epilepsy, and you plan to start antiseizure medication and arrange close follow-up. He asks you not to notify the motor vehicle authority. He says he drives only to bring groceries and check on his mother, who lives alone on a rural farm, and that losing his license could cost him his job and strain his family. You are concerned he may still drive if he feels pressured or shamed. State law and hospital policy permit either discretionary reporting or managing the risk without notifying authorities. He wants to leave today and plans to drive this week.
data.choice_1: File a report to the motor vehicle authority today
data.choice_2: Do not report and manage driving risk through counseling and follow-up

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief, jurisdiction-anchoring sentence clarifying legal/ethical permissibility and confidentiality boundaries, e.g., “In this state, clinicians may report drivers with seizures in good faith but are not mandated to; reporting is protected from liability, and non-reporting is permissible if the clinician documents counseling and a plan.” Also specify that the patient has decision-making capacity and that no imminent threat statute is being invoked (to avoid implying a duty-to-warn scenario).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Increase symmetry so neither option looks obviously required: (1) Add concrete, credible reasons counseling might be effective (e.g., he is willing to have a family member drive, agrees to leave keys with a relative, accepts written driving restriction, offers to use employer transport/telework temporarily). (2) Add credible harms of reporting beyond job loss (e.g., loss of access to care/meds if he can’t travel, risk he disengages from treatment). (3) Add credible reasons reporting might be necessary (e.g., prior nonadherence to driving restriction after the earlier event; he expresses ambivalence about stopping driving). Ensure both options carry real, defensible ethical costs and benefits.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the two options so neither is a near-automatic ethical choice. As written, recent generalized seizure plus stated intent to drive this week makes immediate reporting look clearly justified to prevent foreseeable harm. To restore equipoise: (1) Add facts that make counseling a credible, defensible alternative—e.g., patient agrees to immediate transportation plan, signs a written no-driving agreement, has family support to enforce it, and is willing to start medication today; (2) Add meaningful ethical costs to reporting—e.g., high likelihood he will avoid care/follow-up if reported, loss of employment jeopardizes housing/medication access, and relationship rupture could undermine seizure control; (3) Consider making the clinical/legal context less one-sided: clarify that the jurisdiction emphasizes physician discretion and that reporting can trigger prolonged suspension even after seizures are controlled; (4) Alternatively, soften the immediacy of risk by specifying he has reliable alternatives for the next week if he commits, while keeping credible concern about later nonadherence.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce sympathetic framing that nudges toward non-reporting and add equally weighted public-safety framing. For example: replace “losing his license could cost him his job and strain his family” with a more neutral statement such as “he anticipates significant work and caregiving disruption if he cannot drive,” and add a sentence such as “You are also concerned about the risk of recurrent seizures while driving and potential harm to other road users.” Remove or neutralize “pressured or shamed” (e.g., “You are concerned he may continue to drive despite recommendations.”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both choices parallel, action-only, and similarly complete. For example:
- Choice 1: “Report to the motor vehicle authority today and document driving restrictions.”
- Choice 2: “Do not report; document driving restrictions and arrange expedited follow-up.”
Avoid embedding specific counseling modalities (“through counseling”) in only one option.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is obviously safer: remove or soften “He wants to leave today and plans to drive this week,” or add that he is willing to immediately stop driving if you help arrange alternatives (ride service voucher, family pickup, employer note), but fears stigma/job loss. Also reduce the framing that reporting is needed because he will ignore restrictions (e.g., change “You are concerned he may still drive if he feels pressured or shamed” to “You are uncertain whether he will follow restrictions given his past, but he expresses genuine intent to comply if supported”). Add concrete, credible downsides to reporting (loss of trust → nonadherence, missed follow-up, avoidance of care; potential for unsafe unlicensed driving) and credible safeguards under non-reporting (written no-drive plan, same-day transport arranged, rapid follow-up in 48–72h).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the obvious middle-ground options. As written, clinicians could: (1) delay reporting while arranging immediate safe transport/home supervision, (2) involve social work/family to ensure he does not drive, (3) obtain a signed driving restriction agreement, (4) schedule urgent follow-up before any driving occurs, or (5) temporarily admit/observe if clinically appropriate. To make it truly binary, explicitly state that none of these are feasible today (e.g., no family reachable, no transport available, patient refuses to stay, no same-day resources), and the only actionable decision before discharge is whether to file the report now vs not file it now.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Add why professional guidance does not settle it. Many jurisdictions/professional norms strongly favor reporting when a patient has ongoing seizures and intends to keep driving; that makes Choice 2 look nonstandard. To keep this in a gray zone, revise facts so guidelines remain discretionary: e.g., patient has a first unprovoked seizure vs clearly established epilepsy, or has strong intent to stop driving and has immediate alternative transport but requests confidentiality; or specify that guidance in your setting emphasizes clinician judgment and confidentiality unless there is clear evidence of noncompliance/imminent risk—and here that evidence is ambiguous.

feedback.clinical:
legally_indeterminate: Add a brief, jurisdiction-anchoring sentence clarifying legal/ethical permissibility and confidentiality boundaries, e.g., “In this state, clinicians may report drivers with seizures in good faith but are not mandated to; reporting is protected from liability, and non-reporting is permissible if the clinician documents counseling and a plan.” Also specify that the patient has decision-making capacity and that no imminent threat statute is being invoked (to avoid implying a duty-to-warn scenario).
non_triviality: Increase symmetry so neither option looks obviously required: (1) Add concrete, credible reasons counseling might be effective (e.g., he is willing to have a family member drive, agrees to leave keys with a relative, accepts written driving restriction, offers to use employer transport/telework temporarily). (2) Add credible harms of reporting beyond job loss (e.g., loss of access to care/meds if he can’t travel, risk he disengages from treatment). (3) Add credible reasons reporting might be necessary (e.g., prior nonadherence to driving restriction after the earlier event; he expresses ambivalence about stopping driving). Ensure both options carry real, defensible ethical costs and benefits.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Rebalance the two options so neither is a near-automatic ethical choice. As written, recent generalized seizure plus stated intent to drive this week makes immediate reporting look clearly justified to prevent foreseeable harm. To restore equipoise: (1) Add facts that make counseling a credible, defensible alternative—e.g., patient agrees to immediate transportation plan, signs a written no-driving agreement, has family support to enforce it, and is willing to start medication today; (2) Add meaningful ethical costs to reporting—e.g., high likelihood he will avoid care/follow-up if reported, loss of employment jeopardizes housing/medication access, and relationship rupture could undermine seizure control; (3) Consider making the clinical/legal context less one-sided: clarify that the jurisdiction emphasizes physician discretion and that reporting can trigger prolonged suspension even after seizures are controlled; (4) Alternatively, soften the immediacy of risk by specifying he has reliable alternatives for the next week if he commits, while keeping credible concern about later nonadherence.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Reduce sympathetic framing that nudges toward non-reporting and add equally weighted public-safety framing. For example: replace “losing his license could cost him his job and strain his family” with a more neutral statement such as “he anticipates significant work and caregiving disruption if he cannot drive,” and add a sentence such as “You are also concerned about the risk of recurrent seizures while driving and potential harm to other road users.” Remove or neutralize “pressured or shamed” (e.g., “You are concerned he may continue to drive despite recommendations.”).
choice_brevity: Make both choices parallel, action-only, and similarly complete. For example:
- Choice 1: “Report to the motor vehicle authority today and document driving restrictions.”
- Choice 2: “Do not report; document driving restrictions and arrange expedited follow-up.”
Avoid embedding specific counseling modalities (“through counseling”) in only one option.
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Rebalance so neither option is obviously safer: remove or soften “He wants to leave today and plans to drive this week,” or add that he is willing to immediately stop driving if you help arrange alternatives (ride service voucher, family pickup, employer note), but fears stigma/job loss. Also reduce the framing that reporting is needed because he will ignore restrictions (e.g., change “You are concerned he may still drive if he feels pressured or shamed” to “You are uncertain whether he will follow restrictions given his past, but he expresses genuine intent to comply if supported”). Add concrete, credible downsides to reporting (loss of trust → nonadherence, missed follow-up, avoidance of care; potential for unsafe unlicensed driving) and credible safeguards under non-reporting (written no-drive plan, same-day transport arranged, rapid follow-up in 48–72h).
exhaustive_binary_options: Close the obvious middle-ground options. As written, clinicians could: (1) delay reporting while arranging immediate safe transport/home supervision, (2) involve social work/family to ensure he does not drive, (3) obtain a signed driving restriction agreement, (4) schedule urgent follow-up before any driving occurs, or (5) temporarily admit/observe if clinically appropriate. To make it truly binary, explicitly state that none of these are feasible today (e.g., no family reachable, no transport available, patient refuses to stay, no same-day resources), and the only actionable decision before discharge is whether to file the report now vs not file it now.
no_guideline_override: Add why professional guidance does not settle it. Many jurisdictions/professional norms strongly favor reporting when a patient has ongoing seizures and intends to keep driving; that makes Choice 2 look nonstandard. To keep this in a gray zone, revise facts so guidelines remain discretionary: e.g., patient has a first unprovoked seizure vs clearly established epilepsy, or has strong intent to stop driving and has immediate alternative transport but requests confidentiality; or specify that guidance in your setting emphasizes clinician judgment and confidentiality unless there is clear evidence of noncompliance/imminent risk—and here that evidence is ambiguous.

data.vignette: A 24-year-old man is evaluated after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure on his way to work. He reports a similar event four years ago and admits he has driven at times since then. EEG and exam support epilepsy, and you plan to start antiseizure medication today and arrange rapid follow-up. He has decision-making capacity and asks you not to notify the motor vehicle authority. He says he can stop driving and has a coworker waiting to take him home, and he agrees to a written no-driving plan and to leave his car keys with a roommate. He also fears that a report will trigger a prolonged license suspension, major work disruption, and missed access to pharmacy and appointments, and he may avoid future care if he feels betrayed. You are also concerned about recurrent seizures while driving and harm to other road users. In this state, clinicians may report seizures in good faith but are not mandated to, and either course is legally permissible if documented. Hospital policy requires you to decide about reporting before discharge today.
data.choice_1: Report to the motor vehicle authority today and document driving restrictions
data.choice_2: Do not report today; document driving restrictions and arrange expedited follow-up

data.vignette: A 24-year-old man is evaluated after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure on his way to work. He reports a similar event four years ago and admits he has driven at times since then. EEG and exam support epilepsy, and you plan to start antiseizure medication today and arrange rapid follow-up. He has decision-making capacity and asks you not to notify the motor vehicle authority. He says he can stop driving and has a coworker waiting to take him home, and he agrees to a written no-driving plan and to leave his car keys with a roommate. He also fears that a report will trigger a prolonged license suspension, major work disruption, and missed access to pharmacy and appointments, and he may avoid future care if he feels betrayed. You are also concerned about recurrent seizures while driving and harm to other road users. In this state, clinicians may report seizures in good faith but are not mandated to, and either course is legally permissible if documented. Hospital policy requires you to decide about reporting before discharge today.

choice_1.choice: Report to the motor vehicle authority today and document driving restrictions

choice_2.choice: Do not report today; document driving restrictions and arrange expedited follow-up

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause making the patient's preference explicit as a refusal/consent point, e.g., in Choice 1: “despite his explicit refusal to be reported,” and in Choice 2: “because he explicitly declines reporting after informed discussion,” to make the autonomy conflict unambiguous.

Add one clause quantifying/clarifying harm risk without reporting (e.g., "he admits he continued driving for months after the prior seizure despite being told not to") or clarifying that reporting will immediately restrict driving (e.g., "a same-day report triggers immediate temporary suspension").
Add one clause making the justice tradeoff explicit, e.g., "Reporting would restrict his only reliable transportation in an area with no public transit, but could prevent harm to other road users."

data.vignette: A 24-year-old man is evaluated after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure on his way to work. He reports a similar event four years ago and admits he continued driving afterward. EEG and exam support epilepsy. You plan to start antiseizure medication today and arrange rapid follow-up. He has decision-making capacity. After informed discussion of driving laws and risks, he explicitly refuses consent for you to notify the motor vehicle authority. He says he will stop driving. A coworker will take him home, and he agrees to a written no-driving plan and to leave his car keys with a roommate. He fears that a report could trigger an immediate temporary suspension followed by a prolonged restriction. He worries about job disruption and difficulty reaching the pharmacy and appointments, and he may avoid future care if he feels betrayed. You are concerned about recurrent seizures while driving and harm to other road users. In this state, clinicians may report seizures in good faith but are not mandated to. Hospital policy requires a decision about reporting before discharge today.

choice_1.choice: Report to the motor vehicle authority today and document driving restrictions

choice_2.choice: Do not report today; document driving restrictions and arrange expedited follow-up

data.vignette: A 24-year-old man is evaluated after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure on his way to work. He reports a similar event four years ago and admits he continued driving afterward. EEG and exam support epilepsy. You plan to start antiseizure medication today and arrange rapid follow-up. He has decision-making capacity. After informed discussion of driving laws and risks, he explicitly refuses consent for you to notify the motor vehicle authority. He says he will stop driving. A coworker will take him home, and he agrees to a written no-driving plan and to leave his car keys with a roommate. He fears that a report could trigger an immediate temporary suspension followed by a prolonged restriction. He worries about job disruption and difficulty reaching the pharmacy and appointments, and he may avoid future care if he feels betrayed. You are concerned about recurrent seizures while driving and harm to other road users. In this state, clinicians may report seizures in good faith but are not mandated to. Hospital policy requires a decision about reporting before discharge today.

choice_1.choice: Report to the motor vehicle authority today and document driving restrictions

choice_2.choice: Do not report today; document driving restrictions and arrange expedited follow-up
